form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Pryor (for himself and Mr. Enzi) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

form.official-title: To require the Secretary of Energy to conduct a motor and motor-driven systems market assessment and public awareness program, and for other purposes.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Motor Systems Market Awareness Act of 2014
.

paragraph.text: motors and motor-driven systems account for a significant quantity of the electricity used in the United States;
motor electrical energy use is determined by the efficiency of the motor and the design of the motor-driven system in which the motor and the drive operate;
Federal Government research on commercial and industrial motors and motor-driven system use and efficiency is outdated;
the Bureau of the Census has discontinued collection of data on motor and generator importation, manufacture, shipment, and sales;
the last Department of Energy motor market assessment was conducted in 2002;
motor and motor-driven systems have changed dramatically during the 12-year period ending on the date of enactment of this Act; and
a new motor and motor-driven system market assessment will help United States manufacturers better understand the commercial marketplace and become more globally competitive.
The term Department means the Department of Energy.

subparagraph.text: manufacturers of variable speed drives, including variable frequency drives;
motor end users, including original equipment manufacturers that use motors to drive machinery;
individuals and entities that conduct energy efficiency programs.

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Energy.

subsection.text: The Secretary, in consultation with interested parties, shall conduct a market assessment of motors and motor-driven systems used in the United States.
In conducting the assessment under subsection (a), the Secretary shall—

paragraph.text: develop a profile of commercial and industrial motor and motor-driven system purchase and maintenance practices;
analyze the opportunities (by market segment) for improved energy efficiency and cost savings available through—

subparagraph.text: the use of energy efficient motors, variable speed drives, servo drives, and other control technologies;
substitution of existing motor designs with new and future advanced motor and motor-driven system designs, including—

paragraph.text: evaluate the state of the global supply chain that supports motor and drive technologies (as of the date of enactment of this Act), including—

subparagraph.text: the accessibility and sustainability of key materials;
the progress of research and development directed at decreasing the quantity of heavy rare earth materials required in high energy density permanent magnets; and
factors that may lead to an increase in domestic manufacturing of motor and drive technologies.

subsection.text: Not later than 540 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall publish and make available on the website of the Department a report on the assessment conducted under this section.
The Secretary shall use the assessment and report required under this section—

paragraph.text: to develop recommendations to update the detailed motor and motor-driven system profile on a periodic basis using readily available market information; and
to identify technology and research needs that could be met through joint industry and government partnership.

section.text: Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with interested parties, shall establish a program targeted at motor end-users to increase the awareness of the end-users of—

paragraph.text: motor and motor-driven system procurement and management procedures; and
criteria for making decisions for new, replacement, or repair of motor and motor-driven system components.
